messages.text: This very very old post by Stephan (<https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=3607238>), made me realize that Julia actually has a mechanism to share behavior between types. Just make abstract type and use multiple dispatch to get any combination of abstract types you like. The whole method written to class thing was drilled into my head so much that I forgot what exactly its enabling me to do.

messages.text: I've noticed there are a few "functional languages for parallel array computing" that seems interesting from an ML perspective (e.g. halide, futhark, dexlang). I was curious if people here have experience with those, or are aware of a broad review on the topic comparing pros and cons (in particular, I'm interested about stencil opertations, but I'm curious about the whole approach)

messages.text:
Why do we have optimizations for literal powers, but then they don't inline?

```for i = 1:100
    j += i^5
end```
does a function call to `power_by_squaring` every iteration (where j has integer type)

elements.text: Why do we have optimizations for literal powers, but then they don't inline?

for i = 1:100
    j += i^5
end
does a function call to

every iteration (where j has integer type)

messages.text:
The thesis of this thread is interesting.
<https://twitter.com/jaredpar/status/1355257692005142529?s=19|https://twitter.com/jaredpar/status/1355257692005142529?s=19>.

It's kind of convincing to me:
Either you can recover from an operation failing, or you can not.
If you can recover then you don't care why it failed.
If you cannot then you cannot, do it doesn't matter why it failed.
Half way down it make the argument about file reading.
There are many many reasons it might fail. Possibly encoded into some number of exception types. Possibly different exception types depending on some supposedly orthonal thing like if it is a remote file but that is just following the abstract file API.

Counter is that some errors are programmer errors and this makes identifying them hard.
But maybe erroring out us not the best tool

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/jaredpar|@jaredpar>: .NET exception advice:

Q: What should I throw? 
A: System.Exception 

Q: What should I catch?
A: System.Exception 

The .NET exception model is a Pokémon based system. Gotta catch them all.
attachments.text:
.NET exception advice:

Q: What should I throw? 
A: System.Exception 

Q: What should I catch?
A: System.Exception 

The .NET exception model is a Pokémon based system. Gotta catch them all.

elements.text: The thesis of this thread is interesting.
https://twitter.com/jaredpar/status/1355257692005142529?s=19

.

It's kind of convincing to me:
Either you can recover from an operation failing, or you can not.
If you can recover then you don't care why it failed.
If you cannot then you cannot, do it doesn't matter why it failed.
Half way down it make the argument about file reading.
There are many many reasons it might fail. Possibly encoded into some number of exception types. Possibly different exception types depending on some supposedly orthonal thing like if it is a remote file but that is just following the abstract file API.

Counter is that some errors are programmer errors and this makes identifying them hard.
But maybe erroring out us not the best tool

messages.text: <https://sfconservancy.org/blog/2021/jan/29/elastic-and-ss-public-license/>

attachments.title: On Elastic, its fork, MongoDB, and the SS Public License
attachments.text: Now that SS Public License has doubled its userbase (from one user to two users), folks have been asking us if Conservancy's view on the SS Public License has changed. It hasn't, and our previous two blog posts on MongoDB's license change and Copyleft Equality are still relevant. The only statement we'd like to add is:To our knowledge, there is no individual nor organization who has yet agreed that they will run a project under the SS Public License and be themselves bound by the SS Public License. That license remains a disingenuous proposal until it's put to use in an “inbound=outbound” licensing configuration.
attachments.fallback: Software Freedom Conservancy: On Elastic, its fork, MongoDB, and the SS Public License

messages.text: Speaking of Uniful.jl, I have written a UnitfulCurrencies.jl package (<https://github.com/rmsrosa/UnitfulCurrencies.jl>), but I have not registered it yet. I found out later that there is a UnitfulCurrency.jl, which, however, is marked as archived. So I am pondered whether I change the name of my package or keep it like that since the other one is archived. I am a bit reluctant, but I like the name I chose and can’t think of something more appropriate. Any thoughts?

messages.text: There is this guy who from time to time posts these youtube Julia tutorials on reddit: <https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQwQVlIkbalDzmMnr-0tRhw/videos> - not sure who they are, as they seem to be anonymous

attachments.title: julia for talented amateurs
attachments.text: henlo fren! My name is the Dabbling Doggo and I make wholesome Julia tutorials for talented amateurs everywhere. Julia is a relatively new computer programming language and it's been called the language of the future. My videos are intended for amateurs, hobbyists, tinkerers and enthusiasts who have no programming experience. I am a self-taught hobbyist and Julia is my first programming language. If I can learn it, so can you! I started this channel to help other hobbyists who are interested in learning a programming language, but don't know where to begin. You can start right here. I will show you everything and no previous programming knowledge is required. New videos posted on Sundays.
attachments.fallback: YouTube: julia for talented amateurs

messages.text:
I created a Docker Hub repo that has two versions of Julia from the official repo, and I added Miniconda and Jupyterlab on top.
<https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker/statisticalmice/julia-jupyter>
I found four other repos that match ‘julia-jupyter’, but they were rather old. Of course the ‘jupyter/datascience-notebook’ is much more feature rich, but it’s also 4x as large. I checked that Jupyterlab started from these can run Julia, manually.

elements.text: I created a Docker Hub repo that has two versions of Julia from the official repo, and I added Miniconda and Jupyterlab on top.

I found four other repos that match ‘julia-jupyter’, but they were rather old. Of course the ‘jupyter/datascience-notebook’ is much more feature rich, but it’s also 4x as large. I checked that Jupyterlab started from these can run Julia, manually.

messages.text:
<@UPUBAM63X> Saw these posts in the unisonlang slack, thought about your quest.

Sami Badawi--
> A noob impression.
> I have spent years trying to wrap my head around Haskell. I read the Unison Language Reference and I am baffled how short it is.
> There are so few constructs. I feel I am missing something. If not, why is Unison so much simpler?
Will--
> a shocking proportion of haskell’s surface area is essentially just sugar for a very simple core. I highly recommend this talk from SPJ: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uR_VzYxvbxg>
Anthony Coates--
> Perhaps "shocking" is the wrong way to look at it. Simon et al maintain that small core because it makes it easier to maintain Haskell, and also because it makes it easier to determine when a new addition to the language is some genuinely new functionality, or just a new or more convenient way to use the existing functionality.
...
Sami Badawi--
> That SPJ talk was great.
> I think that the algebraic effects deal with one of Haskell's big weaknesses.
> Monad transformers is a pretty complicated construct for dealing with normal problems.
Will--
> i agree, that’s definitely an area where you can tell that haskell is a “playground” for ideas. hopefully delimited continuations can eventually subsume a lot of the different, complex effect systems
Link: <https://unisonlanguage.slack.com/archives/CLKV43YE4/p1612034587039000>

attachments.title: Into the Core - Squeezing Haskell into Nine Constructors by Simon Peyton Jones
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Into the Core - Squeezing Haskell into Nine Constructors by Simon Peyton Jones
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/uR_VzYxvbxg?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

elements.text:
Saw these posts in the unisonlang slack, thought about your quest.

Sami Badawi--

A noob impression.
I have spent years trying to wrap my head around Haskell. I read the Unison Language Reference and I am baffled how short it is.
There are so few constructs. I feel I am missing something. If not, why is Unison so much simpler?
Will--
a shocking proportion of haskell’s surface area is essentially just sugar for a very simple core. I highly recommend this talk from SPJ:
Anthony Coates--

Perhaps "shocking" is the wrong way to look at it. Simon et al maintain that small core because it makes it easier to maintain Haskell, and also because it makes it easier to determine when a new addition to the language is some genuinely new functionality, or just a new or more convenient way to use the existing functionality.

...
Sami Badawi--

That SPJ talk was great.
I think that the algebraic effects deal with one of Haskell's big weaknesses.
Monad transformers is a pretty complicated construct for dealing with normal problems.
Will--
i agree, that’s definitely an area where you can tell that haskell is a “playground” for ideas. hopefully delimited continuations can eventually subsume a lot of the different, complex effect systems
Link:

messages.text:
Recently came across <https://xmonad.org/|xmonad> while looking for an alternative to i3. And was quite surprised that it was written in pure haskell. I always thought of it as very domain specific(cat theory). Another surprising thing is that it is quite performant and light weight.
Could anyone share why is it so despite the focus of haskell being totally math, and if a similar experiment were possible in Julia?

elements.text: Recently came across
xmonad

while looking for an alternative to i3. And was quite surprised that it was written in pure haskell. I always thought of it as very domain specific(cat theory). Another surprising thing is that it is quite performant and light weight.
Could anyone share why is it so despite the focus of haskell being totally math, and if a similar experiment were possible in Julia?

attachments.title: A module for some additional try catch semantics
attachments.text: Would anyone find something like this useful? I wrote it in order to scratch a bit of an itch I had, but can just as well make it a public package. The aim is to provide try-catch-finally semantics that behaves a bit like Python’s error handling.

Minikube command line output is rather interesting looking. :slightly_smiling_face:
```minikube start                
😄  minikube v1.17.1 on Darwin 11.2
✨  Using the docker driver based on existing profile
👍  Starting control plane node minikube in cluster minikube
🤷  docker "minikube" container is missing, will recreate.
🔥  Creating docker container (CPUs=2, Memory=4000MB) ...
🐳  Preparing Kubernetes v1.20.2 on Docker 20.10.2 ...
🔎  Verifying Kubernetes components...
🌟  Enabled addons: storage-provisioner, default-storageclass
🏄  Done! kubectl is now configured to use "minikube" cluster and "default" namespace by default```

messages.text:
Looking for some advice and helpful comments from my Julia family.
1. I am not really enjoying my postdoc as much. It mainly stems from that the fact that my advisor is non-engaging and dosn't prioritize me. I have five first author papers that are just sitting on her desk (and also obsolete since they were covid19 related, and not relevant/novel anymore). I asked her for a recommendation letter for some TT jobs I applied too, and she still hasn't written me one. There is no mentorship nor an interest in my future career. Is being a postdoc really all about being a completely independent researcher?
2. I have been looking at moving to the industry since TT job market is so bad. However, I just can not shake the feeling that it will mark me as a failure to my current colleagues. More importantly, I just can not shake the feeling that *I will consider myself a failure.* 
Are these all normal feelings? I just have to deal with this anxiety somehow right?

Is being a postdoc really all about being a completely independent researcher?

I have been looking at moving to the industry since TT job market is so bad. However, I just can not shake the feeling that it will mark me as a failure to my current colleagues. More importantly, I just can not shake the feeling that
I will consider myself a failure.
Are these all normal feelings? I just have to deal with this anxiety somehow right?

messages.text: How does the community feel about Mozilla Public License? I loosely like the idea of copy-left, but I have the impression that GPL is too restrictive and sort of poisons other stuff. Is MPL any better?

elements.text: How does the community feel about Mozilla Public License? I loosely like the idea of copy-left, but I have the impression that GPL is too restrictive and sort of poisons other stuff. Is MPL any better?

messages.text: Today I realized how different than each programming community be...:no_mouth:

elements.text: Today I realized how different than each programming community be...

messages.text:
To me copyleft is almost a pyramid scheme.

If I write open source software I want it to result in benifits to people as possible.

So option 1:
I release it under a u restrictive licence like MIT.
100% of people who want software to do the thing I made can use it, and that is great.
High direct benifits

If I release it GPL.
Then maybe 30% of people can't use it because they can't open source their thing. So they have to write software from a scratch. But
Maybe 1% of users end up open sourcing their thing in order to use mine.
So now the benifit I caused it to 70% of my potential users, and to a whole to of extra downstream people.
Lower direct benifit. But maybe higher total benifit.

Which feels to me to be kinda dodgy way to count.
Direct benefits I cause is more important as a measure to me.

root.text: How does the community feel about Mozilla Public License? I loosely like the idea of copy-left, but I have the impression that GPL is too restrictive and sort of poisons other stuff. Is MPL any better?

If I release it GPL.

Maybe 1% of users end up open sourcing their thing in order to use mine.
So now the benifit I caused it to 70% of my potential users, and to a whole to of extra downstream people.
Lower direct benifit. But maybe higher total benifit.

Which feels to me to be kinda dodgy way to count.
Direct benefits I cause is more important as a measure to me.

messages.text: I was wondering how they initially get them underneath as the building is on the ground. Maybe they dig pits for them, then lift? The same problem exists when you want to put the building back on the ground. Lifting first from one side or corner is unlikely to work..

messages.text: Probably similar to how it was done in Chicago in 1854: <https://99percentinvisible.org/episode/episode-86-reversal-of-fortune/>

attachments.title: Reversal of Fortune - 99% Invisible
attachments.text: I fell in love with architecture on the Chicago River. It provides a beautiful vantage point to take in all the marvelous skyscrapers. Unlike other cities that cram you on the sidewalk between looming towers. The Chicago River pushes buildings apart, giving you the opportunity to really take in the city’s glory in glass, steel, and concrete.
attachments.fallback: 99% Invisible: Reversal of Fortune - 99% Invisible

elements.text: Probably similar to how it was done in Chicago in 1854:

messages.text: I noticed <https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/client-libraries/|https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/client-libraries/> does not list Kuber.jl?

attachments.title: Client Libraries
attachments.text: This page contains an overview of the client libraries for using the Kubernetes API from various programming languages. To write applications using the Kubernetes REST API, you do not need to implement the API calls and request/response types yourself. You can use a client library for the programming language you are using. Client libraries often handle common tasks such as authentication for you. Most client libraries can discover and use the Kubernetes Service Account to authenticate if the API client is running inside the Kubernetes cluster, or can understand the kubeconfig file format to read the credentials and the API Server address.
attachments.fallback: Kubernetes: Client Libraries
